White striped pillow + brightly colored books in a bookcase. 

And that's just one wall. The whole house is pretty like a storybook but loud. 

I've been so stressed, depressed, agitated, moody.

When sensory overloads at its worst I can't form straight thoughts or hold them for

We moved in with family not too long ago. The house is lovely & I'm really thankful. 

It's loud. 

There's a wood panel wall with a brick fireplace + multiple windows with white frame + gold mirror + lamps + clock + tan decorative bird cage + plants + green chair + blue and

I could have worded that better. The word I was looking for was autopilot. Like I don't even notice I'm accommodating or reacting/adjusting to sensitivities a lot of the time. It's just automatic 🤷🏼‍♀️

Or I know something is off with how I feel but no idea why
So I'm curious, bored and thinking a lot about this subject and want to know what other people's experiences are.

I never really gave much thought to it honestly. 

My sensitivities were always there, directing a sizeable portion of my existence without much notice from me.

I notice my kids' sensory aversions more than my own lately tbh.

What helps or doesn't? Does anything make it worse?

If you could give 1 piece of advice to a newly realized autistic person or their caregiver on the topic of sensory overload what would it be?

What do you wish you had learned earlier than you did?

Can we talk about sensory overload? 

Not talk like I say a bunch of random stuff about it. I don't know enough outside of my own experiences to fancy myself as any sort of authority on the topic.

But how do you experience sensory overload in your own life? 

#ActuallyAutistic

I've also been encouraging them to think about each body zone when they wake up and try to notice how it feels so they can more easily pickup any changes but so far they aren't interested in that because it's boring 😂

I have no idea if this is a good approach or if it's going to help them enough. I'm just trying to equip with the skills they need to care for themselves and access care for things that need more intervention. 

Long-ass ramble but maybe it makes sense 😅

11/11

We practice writing stuff down to share with the doctor since its really difficult to talk sometimes & harder to remember what needs to be said. 

We talk about how sometimes doctors may be mistaken or not take us seriously because we don't look "matched up" for the symptoms 10/?

We look at anything that could have changed environmentally or routinewise. 

And we document anything we find. Sometimes if we can't find anything wrong I give a dose of Tylenol & check how they are feeling. My kids have realized their head was hurting AFTER meds resolved it 9/?

My meningitis, hellp syndrome, HG. my newborn's heart failure, etc.. 

So when we notice more frequent meltdown/shutdowns we triage. I use an otoscope on ears, we look at teeth, take temperature, inspect bodies (with consent of course if they can't do it themself) for injury 8/?

Instead of actually looking into what I was saying because he didn't look like he was in pain or feeling unwell. 

Every life threatening illness for my kids & myself has been met with the same dismissal from doctors. 

7/?

Which brings me to the 2nd important thing I'm trying to teach them. 

How to advocate for themselves.

I told every doctor that day that his o2 was low at sleep, his coloring on his ears & lips were blue. his heart rate was 20's-30's at sleep. They asked why I had 02 monitor 6/?

The day he was admitted to the hospital I had taken him to his pediatrician, urgent care, the ER next to my house and finally children's hospital where they admitted him pretty much immediately after they actually listened to me explain what was going on.

5/?

My oldest when he was like 5 had to be hospitalized for pneumonia because his o2 was in the 80s with any exertion, and his kidneys stopped making urine. He was so sick. 

I kept taking him to the doctor because he was off and they kept sending us home. 

4/?

Like I knew it was bad but I had no idea it was THAT bad.

I've noticed similar with my kids. When they are cranky, irritable, meltingdown when their everyday sensory needs are being met. They often don't realize they are in pain

3/?

Months ago I started having meltdowns daily, was irritated and hated everything. Fucking miserable and I had no idea why. I turned into a raging bitch

*spoiler alert* I had pain, i knew I had pain but i had no idea it was at the level incredible high level it was at. 
2/?

One of the most important things I'm trying to teach my autistic kids is how to first notice then decipher what their bodies are telling them. 

In my mid 30s I'm still learning too. It's hard and I'm not good at it. 1/?

Then I burn out, and end up profoundly disabled and unable to work for at least 2 years.

But with accommodations, I thrive.

I can make the computer systems i work with do things my bosses didn't even know were possible lol. 

I'm coming out of a burnout & debating working again

The stress of working without accomodations & having to mask has pushed me to multiple mental breakdowns & inpatient hospitalizations. Now that I've been a working adult for over 10 years. I've discovered I can usually last 1-2 years working before everything falls apart.. /4

A coworker that I had trained for a YEAR at a recent job loudly declaired that "ewww, I would never want to work with someone like that." When autism came up in conversation.

I can't figure out if I'm more scared of the consequences of disclosing or the consequences of not /3

For the most part I have kept the fact that I'm Autistic to myself and immediate family.

Initially I was very open about it, but after losing a job I had for years, where I had been promoted and was in training to be a PM shortly after disclosing, and.. /2

Would any fellow Autistics be willing to share how they handle disclosing that they are Autistic? If you're completely open about it, share with just a certain people or choose to keep it private and thoughts/experiences with disclosure?
